text: The Song of Songs, that [is] Solomon's.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let him kiss me with kisses of his mouth, For better [are] thy loves than wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: For fragrance [are] thy perfumes good. Perfume emptied out -- thy name, Therefore have virgins loved thee!
speaker: Narrator

text: Draw me: after thee we run, The king hath brought me into his inner chambers, We do joy and rejoice in thee, We mention thy loves more than wine, Uprightly they have loved thee!
speaker: Narrator

text: Dark [am] I, and comely, daughters of Jerusalem, As tents of Kedar, as curtains of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear me not, because I [am] very dark, Because the sun hath scorched me, The sons of my mother were angry with me, They made me keeper of the vineyards, My vineyard -- my own -- I have not kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: Declare to me, thou whom my soul hath loved, Where thou delightest, Where thou liest down at noon, For why am I as one veiled, By the ranks of thy companions?
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou knowest not, O fair among women, Get thee forth by the traces of the flock, And feed thy kids by the shepherds' dwellings!
speaker: Narrator

text: To my joyous one in chariots of Pharaoh, I have compared thee, my friend,
speaker: Narrator

text: Comely have been thy cheeks with garlands, Thy neck with chains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Garlands of gold we do make for thee, With studs of silver!
speaker: Narrator

text: While the king [is] in his circle, My spikenard hath given its fragrance.
speaker: Narrator

text: A bundle of myrrh [is] my beloved to me, Between my breasts it lodgeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: A cluster of cypress [is] my beloved to me, In the vineyards of En-Gedi!
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, thou [art] fair, my friend, Lo, thou [art] fair, thine eyes [are] doves!
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, thou [art] fair, my love, yea, pleasant, Yea, our couch [is] green,
speaker: Narrator

text: The beams of our houses [are] cedars, Our rafters [are] firs, I [am] a rose of Sharon, a lily of the valleys!
speaker: Narrator

text: As a lily among the thorns,
speaker: Narrator

text: So [is] my friend among the daughters!
speaker: Narrator

text: As a citron among trees of the forest, So [is] my beloved among the sons, In his shade I delighted, and sat down, And his fruit [is] sweet to my palate.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath brought me in unto a house of wine, And his banner over me [is] love,
speaker: Narrator

text: Sustain me with grape-cakes, Support me with citrons, for I [am] sick with love.
speaker: Narrator

text: His left hand [is] under my head, And his right doth embrace me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, By the roes or by the hinds of the field, Stir not up nor wake the love till she please!
speaker: Narrator

text: The voice of my beloved! lo, this -- he is coming, Leaping on the mountains, skipping on the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: My beloved [is] like to a roe, Or to a young one of the harts. Lo, this -- he is standing behind our wall, Looking from the windows, Blooming from the lattice.
speaker: Narrator

text: My beloved hath answered and said to me, `Rise up, my friend, my fair one, and come away,
speaker: Narrator

text: For lo, the winter hath passed by, The rain hath passed away -- it hath gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flowers have appeared in the earth, The time of the singing hath come, And the voice of the turtle was heard in our land,
speaker: Narrator

text: The fig-tree hath ripened her green figs, And the sweet-smelling vines have given forth fragrance, Rise, come, my friend, my fair one, yea, come away.
speaker: Narrator

text: My dove, in clefts of the rock, In a secret place of the ascent, Cause me to see thine appearance, Cause me to hear thy voice, For thy voice [is] sweet, and thy appearance comely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seize ye for us foxes, Little foxes -- destroyers of vineyards, Even our sweet-smelling vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: My beloved [is] mine, and I [am] his, Who is delighting among the lilies,
speaker: Narrator

text: Till the day doth break forth, And the shadows have fled away, Turn, be like, my beloved, To a roe, or to a young one of the harts, On the mountains of separation!
speaker: Narrator

text: On my couch by night, I sought him whom my soul hath loved; I sought him, and I found him not!
speaker: Narrator

text: -- Pray, let me rise, and go round the city, In the streets and in the broad places, I seek him whom my soul hath loved! -- I sought him, and I found him not.
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchmen have found me, (Who are going round about the city), `Him whom my soul have loved saw ye?'
speaker: Narrator

text: But a little I passed on from them, Till I found him whom my soul hath loved! I seized him, and let him not go, Till I brought him in unto the house of my mother -- And the chamber of her that conceived me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, By the roes or by the hinds of the field, Stir not up nor wake the love till she please!
speaker: Narrator

text: Who [is] this coming up from the wilderness, Like palm-trees of smoke, Perfumed [with] myrrh and frankincense, From every powder of the merchant?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, his couch, that [is] Solomon's, Sixty mighty ones [are] around it, Of the mighty of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: All of them holding sword, taught of battle, Each his sword by his thigh, for fear at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: A palanquin king Solomon made for himself, Of the wood of Lebanon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Its pillars he made of silver, Its bottom of gold, its seat of purple, Its midst lined [with] love, By the daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go forth, and look, ye daughters of Zion, On king Solomon, with the crown, With which his mother crowned him, In the day of his espousals, And in the day of the joy of his heart!
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, thou [art] fair, my friend, lo, thou [art] fair, Thine eyes [are] doves behind thy veil, Thy hair as a row of the goats That have shone from mount Gilead,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy teeth as a row of the shorn ones That have come up from the washing, For all of them are forming twins, And a bereaved one is not among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a thread of scarlet [are] thy lips, And thy speech [is] comely, As the work of the pomegranate [is] thy temple behind thy veil,
speaker: Narrator

text: As the tower of David [is] thy neck, built for an armoury, The chief of the shields are hung on it, All shields of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy two breasts [are] as two fawns, Twins of a roe, that are feeding among lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Till the day doth break forth, And the shadows have fled away, I will get me unto the mountain of myrrh, And unto the hill of frankincense.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou [art] all fair, my friend, And a blemish there is not in thee. Come from Lebanon, O spouse,
speaker: Narrator

text: Come from Lebanon, come thou in. Look from the top of Amana, From the top of Shenir and Hermon, From the habitations of lions, From the mountains of leopards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast emboldened me, my sister-spouse, Emboldened me with one of thine eyes, With one chain of thy neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: How wonderful have been thy loves, my sister-spouse, How much better have been thy loves than wine, And the fragrance of thy perfumes than all spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy lips drop honey, O spouse, Honey and milk [are] under thy tongue, And the fragrance of thy garments [Is] as the fragrance of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text: A garden shut up [is] my sister-spouse, A spring shut up -- a fountain sealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy shoots a paradise of pomegranates, With precious fruits,
speaker: Narrator

text: Cypresses with nard -- nard and saffron, Cane and cinnamon, With all trees of frankincense, Myrrh and aloes, with all chief spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fount of gardens, a well of living waters, And flowings from Lebanon!
speaker: Narrator

text: Awake, O north wind, and come, O south, Cause my garden to breathe forth, its spices let flow, Let my beloved come to his garden, And eat its pleasant fruits!
speaker: Narrator

text: I have come in to my garden, my sister-spouse, I have plucked my myrrh with my spice, I have eaten my comb with my honey, I have drunk my wine with my milk. Eat, O friends, drink, Yea, drink abundantly, O beloved ones!
speaker: Narrator

text: I am sleeping, but my heart waketh: The sound of my beloved knocking! `Open to me, my sister, my friend, My dove, my perfect one, For my head is filled [with] dew, My locks [with] drops of the night.'
speaker: Narrator

text: I have put off my coat, how do I put it on? I have washed my feet, how do I defile them?
speaker: Narrator

text: My beloved sent his hand from the net-work, And my bowels were moved for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I rose to open to my beloved, And my hands dropped myrrh, Yea, my fingers flowing myrrh, On the handles of the lock.
speaker: Narrator

text: I opened to my beloved, But my beloved withdrew -- he passed on, My soul went forth when he spake, I sought him, and found him not. I called him, and he answered me not.
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchmen who go round about the city, Found me, smote me, wounded me, Keepers of the walls lifted up my veil from off me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, If ye find my beloved -- What do ye tell him? that I [am] sick with love!
speaker: Narrator

text: What [is] thy beloved above [any] beloved, O fair among women? What [is] thy beloved above [any] beloved, That thus thou hast adjured us?
speaker: Narrator

text: My beloved [is] clear and ruddy, Conspicuous above a myriad!
speaker: Narrator

text: His head [is] pure gold -- fine gold, His locks flowing, dark as a raven,
speaker: Narrator

text: His eyes as doves by streams of water, Washing in milk, sitting in fulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: His cheeks as a bed of the spice, towers of perfumes, His lips [are] lilies, dropping flowing myrrh,
speaker: Narrator

text: His hands rings of gold, set with beryl, His heart bright ivory, covered with sapphires,
speaker: Narrator

text: His limbs pillars of marble, Founded on sockets of fine gold, His appearance as Lebanon, choice as the cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text: His mouth is sweetness -- and all of him desirable, This [is] my beloved, and this my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem!
speaker: Narrator

text: Whither hath thy beloved gone, O fair among women? Whither hath thy beloved turned, And we seek him with thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: My beloved went down to his garden, To the beds of the spice, To delight himself in the gardens, and to gather lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text: I [am] my beloved's, and my beloved [is] mine, Who is delighting himself among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fair [art] thou, my friend, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Awe-inspiring as bannered hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn round thine eyes from before me, Because they have made me proud. Thy hair [is] as a row of the goats, That have shone from Gilead,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy teeth as a row of the lambs, That have come up from the washing, Because all of them are forming twins, And a bereaved one is not among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the work of the pomegranate [is] thy temple behind thy veil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sixty are queens, and eighty concubines, And virgins without number.
speaker: Narrator

text: One is my dove, my perfect one, One she [is] of her mother, The choice one she [is] of her that bare her, Daughters saw, and pronounce her happy, Queens and concubines, and they praise her.
speaker: Narrator

text: `Who [is] this that is looking forth as morning, Fair as the moon -- clear as the sun, Awe-inspiring as bannered hosts?'
speaker: Narrator

text: Unto a garden of nuts I went down, To look on the buds of the valley, To see whither the vine had flourished, The pomegranates had blossomed --
speaker: Narrator

text: I knew not my soul, It made me -- chariots of my people Nadib.
speaker: Narrator

text: Return, return, O Shulammith! Return, return, and we look upon thee. What do ye see in Shulammith?
speaker: Narrator

text: As the chorus of `Mahanaim.' How beautiful were thy feet with sandals, O daughter of Nadib. The turnings of thy sides [are] as ornaments, Work of the hands of an artificer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy waist [is] a basin of roundness, It lacketh not the mixture, Thy body a heap of wheat, fenced with lilies,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy two breasts as two young ones, twins of a roe,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy neck as a tower of the ivory, Thine eyes pools in Heshbon, near the gate of Bath-Rabbim, Thy face as a tower of Lebanon looking to Damascus,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy head upon thee as Carmel, And the locks of thy head as purple, The king is bound with the flowings!
speaker: Narrator

text: How fair and how pleasant hast thou been, O love, in delights.
speaker: Narrator

text: This thy stature hath been like to a palm, And thy breasts to clusters.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said, `Let me go up on the palm, Let me lay hold on its boughs, Yea, let thy breasts be, I pray thee, as clusters of the vine, And the fragrance of thy face as citrons,
speaker: Narrator

text: And thy palate as the good wine --' Flowing to my beloved in uprightness, Strengthening the lips of the aged!
speaker: Narrator

text: I [am] my beloved's, and on me [is] his desire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, my beloved, we go forth to the field,
speaker: Narrator

text: We lodge in the villages, we go early to the vineyards, We see if the vine hath flourished, The sweet smelling-flower hath opened. The pomegranates have blossomed, There do I give to thee my loves;
speaker: Narrator

text: The mandrakes have given fragrance, And at our openings all pleasant things, New, yea, old, my beloved, I laid up for thee!
speaker: Narrator

text: Who doth make thee as a brother to me, Sucking the breasts of my mother? I find thee without, I kiss thee, Yea, they do not despise me,
speaker: Narrator

text: I lead thee, I bring thee in unto my mother's house, She doth teach me, I cause thee to drink of the perfumed wine, Of the juice of my pomegranate,
speaker: Narrator

text: His left hand [is] under my head, And his right doth embrace me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, How ye stir up, And how ye wake the love till she please!
speaker: Narrator

text: Who [is] this coming from the wilderness, Hasting herself for her beloved? Under the citron-tree I have waked thee, There did thy mother pledge thee, There she gave a pledge [that] bare thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set me as a seal on thy heart, as a seal on thine arm, For strong as death is love, Sharp as Sheol is jealousy, Its burnings [are] burnings of fire, a flame of Jah!
speaker: Narrator

text: Many waters are not able to quench the love, And floods do not wash it away. If one give all the wealth of his house for love, Treading down -- they tread upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have a little sister, and breasts she hath not, What do we do for our sister, In the day that it is told of her?
speaker: Narrator

text: If she is a wall, we build by her a palace of silver. And if she is a door, We fashion by her board-work of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: I [am] a wall, and my breasts as towers, Then I have been in his eyes as one finding peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon hath a vineyard in Baal-Hamon, He hath given the vineyard to keepers, Each bringeth for its fruit a thousand silverlings;
speaker: Narrator

text: My vineyard -- my own -- is before me, The thousand [is] for thee, O Solomon. And the two hundred for those keeping its fruit. O dweller in gardens!
speaker: Narrator

text: The companions are attending to thy voice, Cause me to hear. Flee, my beloved, and be like to a roe,
speaker: Narrator

text: Or to a young one of the harts on mountains of spices!
speaker: Narrator
